desc: (Let us see I can get the message of what I need across this time...)I want to promote the website [url removed, login to view] through a short video that will show how it works and what it is. It will contain shots from the website operations of course, and before that an 'intro' that will explain in brief what [url removed, login to view] is all about.You DON'T have to animate anything.  Actually the video will be _very_ similar to these training videos here: [url removed, login to view]So we only have to use 'static' images that will only 'move around the screen'.  Of course adding some 'depth' with the use of shadows, lighting and even After Effects is highly desirable - as opposed to having these 'flat' 2D elements moving around the screen.  We can even use libraries of 3D icons, like in the attached example.The last part of the video will mostly show how the subscription process works and how the games are played and users get ranked based on their scores, as if there was a screen-capturing software 'taping' some user browsing through the website and playing the games.We can even use 'snapshots' of the games - that are quite fancy and colorfull by themselves anyway - to make the presentation more attractive.A native British or American narrator will be used.  I will provide the text.Regarding the budget, I cannot go too far above $400.Duration of the video: not more than 90 seconds. Actually, the shorter and more comprehensive the presentation, the better.
title: Professional-looking explainer video

desc: I started War of Awards in 2015 with a small crowd at the LA Cosplay Con during E3.  The concept of War of Awards is essentially debates about what will/should win awards.  I kept it on track but had to hire a camera person who did not really deliver the style I asked.To make sure I got the right style of camera work, I shot it myself with a small rig in 2016 at PAX South in San Antonio:[url removed, login to view]But being absent as host meant it went off the rails in places, and regrettably I did not switch to picture mode occasionally to get very high resolution crowd shots for marketing/web purposes.So my main goal for the next event in Denver is to get those pictures if we have a decent crowd, but also find someone who can match the orbital video style and demonstrate it beforehand with a test run that I will suggest and describe.I'll be hosting and working the crowds again, curious to see how the esports community responds.The venue is National Western Complex where they are having the Dreamhack show.  Because this is the first year of the show, I'm not sure what to expect and am hesitant to invest in a full crew.  I'm hoping to get the right person who is a jack of all trades and come away with solid pics and b-roll, then possibly go bigger next year with full sponsorship.I think we are scheduled for 4:30pm on October 21.  Still confirming time.
title: My Photography Project

We would like to cover the action in a single sweeping camera move, and then we will transition to the real mattress on a sound stage with a model laying on it. Lastly, we would like the animation to be on an infinite white background.I have attached our brand's rendering of the separate layers for reference.Here is an example of a commercial that utilizes a similar animation - [url removed, login to view]
